title: New Laverty sale sees 272 works on the block
text:
The Lavertys were introduced to Aboriginal art during a visit to the Brisbane Expo in 1988, after they had mainly focused on collecting the works of white Australian artists.

Apparently the art from Papunya, central Australia, took them by storm, unleashing a buying spree that saw them acquire hundreds of works from prints to large canvases – an astounding range of acquisitions. More than half the 272 works in this sale are by Indigenous artists – adding to the hundreds of native artworks already dispersed by the Lavertys.

Lorna Fencer Napurrurla's Spring Water at Yumarlpa is expected to sell for $7000 to $9000.

Eschewing art auctions, the couple bought almost entirely from galleries, or, as with much of their Aboriginal art, in the field from local artists and co-ops during their extensive travels.

The couple knew and supported Kovacs, based in Bundeena south of Sydney, and the latest sale is dominated by works demonstrating the changing face of her art over a 40-year painting career.

Walangkura Napanangka’s Untitled

Eleven of her pictures will go under the hammer next week, ranging from Orange Glow from 2008, 76cm by 56cm in acrylic paint on paper estimated at $4000 to $6000, to Wonder 2017, a 1.2m by 84cm oil at $10,000 to $15,000. Dallas, a 2004 picture 76cm by 1m, is $10,000 to $15,000. At the upper levels, priced at around $30,000, are the 2m wide paintings Ghost from 2006 and For You from 2004. Works from the early 2000s include Bamboo and Sparkler, both around 165cm high and estimated at $12,000 to $18,000. In recent times her work has veered more into spidery “wire works” which are also well represented here.

The Art Sales Digest database lists Kovacs’ most expensive picture at auction as Boot from 2001, which brought $87,840 as part of the Laverty collection at Bonhams in March 2013, and the 2.4m wide Float, which sold for $57,600 from the Gary Sands collection at Shapiro in February this year. Three other Kovacs from the Lavertys are on the records as having sold for more than $40,000.

Advertisement

Other artists evidently favoured by the medical couple include Richard Larter, Robert Klippel, Tom Risley and Michael Taylor, while among indigenous art, works by Lorna Fencer Napurrurla and Paddy Wainburranga stand out. It is strong in Papunya Tula artists, including Walangkura Napanangka, and works from Balgo and the Tiwi Islands.

There are a number of prints by the likes of Kitty Kantilla, Queenie McKenzie and John Mawurndjul, some now relatively rare.

Demonstrating the Lavertys’ shifting tastes over the years, a couple of paintings bought in the 1980s include Reginald Borstel’s study of a French clipper Nal, 1907, and P Brunswick’s racehorse study Ampier from 1903.

The auctioneer’s chief executive Andrew Shapiro will not be drawn on whether new records are likely, but clearly with works fresh to the market with the imprimatur of a distinguished collecting couple it would not surprise.

description: The latest sale from the Laverty collection sees 272 lots go under the hammer – more than half by Indigenous artists.
